text.p: (Compiled for Reuters by Media Monitors)
THE AUSTRALIAN FINANCIAL REVIEW

The government has offered to conduct a review of the five percent general tariff levied on most manufactured imports as part of Australia's confidential trade liberalisation plan for this year's APEC negotiations. The review, to be conducted some time in the next three years, would take into account other APEC members' commitment to opening markets. Page 1.

The Papua New Guinea government has agreed to allow Orogen Minerals to use part of the proceeds of its A$260 million float to pay for a previously unheld 15 percent stake in the Porgera gold mine in the Papua New Guinea highlands and a 20.5 percent stake in the untapped Gobe oil fields. Page 21.

Kerry Packer's decision to sort the Packer group into media and non-media assets six months ago suggests that the sale of some of his share in Melbourne's Crown Casino this week was not a sign of imminent media plays. The Packer family-controlled public ompany Publishing and Broadcasting Ltd controls the media interests and the privately owned Packer vehicle Consolidated Press Holdings operates outside the Australian media. Page 21.

Following the float of its parent company, Glorious Sun Enterprises in Hong Kong this week, Australia's second largest denim clothing retailer JeansWest Australia is planning to expand it chain from 146 stores to 180. Glorious Sun's prospectus shows that JeansWest's Australian revenues climbed from A$65 million to A$82 million in 1995/96. Page 22.

National Mutual Holdings staff have criticised NatMut for its policy on share trading by employees and directors who have accepted shares in the upcoming float. Claiming that the policy is draconian, staff say the measure was announced after employees had committed to accepting shares in the eligible policyholder section phase of the float which closed on August 23. Page 22.

Within 24 hours of Kerry Packer's Consolidated Press Holdings announcing the sell-off of almost two-thirds of its stake in the Melbourne Crown Casino, 75 million shares were placed with investors in Australia, North America, Europe and Asia by BZW Corporate Finance at A$2.72 a share. Page 23.
THE AUSTRALIAN

Following a finding in June that an exclusive agreement between Kerry Stokes' Golden West Network and the Packer family's Nine Network was anti-competitive, the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission is preparing to take legal action against the two parties because of their refusal to unwind the programming deal in regional Western Australia. Page 27.

In her annual report, Commonwealth Ombudsman Philippa Smith has warned that the Australian Taxation Office lacks consistency and accountability, following complaints from taxpayers over the ATO's tendency to reverse favourable advance opinions and complaints from business people who claim they were given sales tax rulings that were inconsistent with those given to their competitors. Page 27.

At meetings yesterday, West Australian Premier Richard Court and State Resources Development Minister Colin Barnett are believed to have criticised Cornelius Norkstroker, the chairman of the committee of managing directors of the Royal Dutch/Shell Group, for failing to make a quick decision on whether to expand the existing North West Shelf LNG project, duplicate it in partnership with the Gorgon gas reserves, or develop Gorgon has a stand-alone project. Page 27.

The only big accounting firm to detail its performance in an annual report, KPMG yesterday disclosed a 9.3 percent boost in revenue to A$329 million for the year to June 30, building on a six percent rise the previous year. The firm's gross profitabiliy increased to 54 percent of revenue, compared with 53 percent previously. Page 27.

Australian investors will be able to buy shares in Papua New Guinea's multi-million-dollar float of Mineral Resources Development Co at A$1.70 each today. The sale of up to 49 percent of the state-owned mining investment house, through the float company Orogen Minerals Ltd is expected to raise A$260 million. Page 27.

Treasurer Peter Costello and the Foreign Investment Review Board yesterday gave official approval for Air New Zealand's purchase of half of Ansett Australia, making way for an announcement by the Australian and New Zealand governments on a single aviation market between the countries. Page 29.
THE SYDNEY MORNING HERALD

The Papua New Guinea Government is seeking to raise about A$342 million from the sharemarket float of Orogen Resources. Australian and New Zealand investors will be offered shares at A$1.70 each and Papua New Guinea investors will receive a 10 percent discount on the shares. Page 29.

Although the Federal Court yesterday upheld a decision handed down by Justice Sackville last December which declared the Offset Alpine shareholders, represented by Bank Leuml Le-Israel and EBC Zurich AG, had broken two sections of the Corporations law, the Australian Securities Commission will look to tighten up foreign shareholder legislation after failing to force the shareholders to reveal themselves. Page 29.

Sydney Harbour Casino shares jumped 12 cents to A$1.85 in the first 10 minutes of trading yesterday following rumours that after cutting its stake in Melbourne casino operator Crown, Kerry Packer's Consolidated Press Holdings would bid for Showboat, which owns 26 percent of Sydney Harbour Casino and controls 85 percent of its management contract. Page 29.

Overtaking an alternative float proposal via a backdoor listing through Telecasters North Queensland, John Singleton Advertising is close to making a decision on putting its five percent shareholding in Ten Network into a new sharemarket-listed unit trust. If JSA decides to divest its shareholding, others, including Isi Leibler and Robert Whyte, are expected to follow. Page 31.

After yesterday receiving conditional federal government approval for the acquisition of TNT's 50 percent stake in Ansett Australia, Air New Zealand has only to get approval from a special meeting of Air NZ shareholders on September 27 before it can expand into the Australian domestic market. Page 31.

Stan Quinlivan, chairman of Western Australian charter airline Skippers Aviation, says Hazelton Airlines has suffered from poor accounting decisions and must cut costs to improve efficiency and return to profitability. Skippers Aviation acquired 17.3 percent of Hazelton in July and has since raised its stake to 19.87 percent. Page 31.
THE AGE

Following Consolidated Press Holdings' realisation of A$204 million from the sale of Crown Casino shares "for use in other transactions", shares in 26 percent-owner of Sydney Harbour Casino, Las Vegas-based Showboat, rose 12 percent, with 800,000 shares changing hands. Page B1.

The Australian Securities Commission has announced that from 1 October it will provide class order relief for companies distributing their prospectuses electronically, provided a paper prospectus is also lodged with the ASC. Page B1.

With Holden's V8 engine sales declining at the rate of about one percent a year for the past three years, the car maker will stop building V8 engines in Australia within a few months, depending on the market's reaction to the new supercharged V6 engine rleased this week for the Calais, Statesman and Caprice models. Page B1.

Pharmaceuticals group F.H. Faulding yesterday announced its acquisition of Melbourne scientific research and development company Soltec, in a payment including a share issue to the vendors worth A$11.5 million. Soltec has licensing or development arrangements with 14 of the world's top pharmaceutical companies. Page B2.

The Papua New Guinea Government will float Orogen Resources on the Australian Stock Exchange, seeking to raise about A$342 million. Orogen is expected to rank among the top 150 ASX listed companies. Page B2.

The A$65.7 million raised from Glorious Sun Enterprises' successful Hong Kong float will be used to expand the JeansWest retail chain in Australia, China and New Zealand and to develop its manufacturing base. JeansWest plans to open another 20 stores in Australia in the next 12 months. Page B3.
-- Reuters Sydney Newsroom 61-2 373-1800
